items.author: Peter Travers
items.content: No one interested in the power and magic of movies should miss it.

items.author: Desmond Ryan
items.content: Aronofsky has fashioned a chilling vision that lives up to the caustic irony of its title and gives us a nightmare that is not lightly forgotten.

items.author: Jonathan Foreman
items.content: A powerful fable about love and addiction that manages to be darkly humorous when it isn't graphic or harrowing in the extreme.

items.author: Michael Atkinson
items.content: May be an elaborate stunt, a bungee jump, but even so, it's forceful enough to leave a rare palpitating residue.

items.author: Wesley Morris
items.content: It's one of the most beautifully unpleasant movies ever made - its reverse charge being that it is no fun at all.

items.author: Ken Fox
items.content: Aronofsky has given us a well-acted, gorgeously overwrought and luridly entertaining exploitation flick -- a midnight movie for future generations.

items.author: Desson Thomson
items.content: While director Aronofsky pistol-whips your attention with his style, the characters (mostly relegated to human mannequins in Aronofsky's visual schemes) suffer big time.

items.author: William Arnold
items.content: To be fair, Aronofsky has a knack for stylistic overkill, and his hammering onslaught is undeniably riveting, at first anyway.

items.author: Ernest Hardy
items.content: Too self-consciously dark, too aware of its long, murky, art-designed descent into the underbelly of America's addictive personality.

items.author: Stephen Hunter
items.content: In the end the movie goes nowhere a hundred movies haven't already been and tells us nothing we don't already know. It does so with so much violent energy, however, it's like four brutal years at film school crammed into an hour and a half.
